title: 109_hr6328
content: The Act is titled the "Congressional Commission on the Abolition of Modern-Day Slavery Act" and defines modern-day slavery as various forms of exploitation including involuntary servitude, forced labor, child labor, debt bondage, trafficking in persons, forced marriage, and more. Congress finds that modern-day slavery takes various forms and occurs in different industries, violating the dignity of individuals through violence and exploitation. The Universal Declaration of Human Rights prohibits slavery in all its forms, and both the United States and the international community are committed to combating this issue. The United States and the international community are committed to abolishing modern-day slavery in accordance with various international conventions and protocols. The United States upholds the Declaration of Independence and the 13th amendment, which recognize the inherent dignity of all people and prohibit slavery and forced labor. The United States prioritizes combating trafficking in persons, a form of modern-day slavery, through legislation like the Trafficking Victims Protection Act. Importation of goods produced by forced labor is prohibited under the Tariff Act of 1930. Establishment of Commission. The congressional Commission on the Abolition of Modern-Day Slavery is established with 12 members appointed by various leaders based on expertise in combating modern-day slavery. The Commission on the Abolition of Modern-Day Slavery members will be appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment for life. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Co-chairpersons will be designated by the Speaker of the House and the Senate majority leader. The Commission's first meeting must be held within 60 days of the Act's enactment, and meetings will be called by either co-chairperson. The Commission on the Abolition of Modern-Day Slavery will meet at the call of either Co-chairperson. A majority of members will constitute a quorum for meetings or hearings. The Commission on the Abolition of Modern-Day Slavery will meet as called by either Co-chairperson, with a majority of members needed to constitute a quorum for meetings or hearings. The Commission will conduct a study on modern-day slavery, including factors contributing to it like social structures, law enforcement failures, corruption, and vulnerable populations in conflict areas or states facing upheaval. They will also review relevant governmental programs. The Commission will review programs of relevant governmental agencies and examine efforts by foreign countries and multilateral organizations to prevent or combat modern-day slavery. The Commission will review programs of relevant governmental agencies and examine efforts by foreign countries and multilateral organizations to prevent or combat modern-day slavery. The Commission aims to advise Congress on supporting efforts to eradicate modern-day slavery, evaluate best practices to prevent it, and identify countries with significant numbers of victims. Additionally, experts from relevant NGOs will be included in the review process. The curr_chunk provides a comprehensive evaluation of best practices to rescue and rehabilitate victims of modern-day slavery, ensure prosecution of acts of modern-day slavery, evaluate effectiveness of US laws prohibiting goods produced through forced labor, and assess policies towards countries tolerating modern-day slavery. The Commission will evaluate models and strategies to prevent, rescue, and rehabilitate victims of modern-day slavery, prosecute offenders, and increase education about modern-day slavery. It will also examine the economic impact of successful anti-slavery efforts and promote education and awareness among high-risk populations in the US. Recommendations for legislative and administrative actions to combat modern-day slavery will be developed. The Commission will submit a report to Congress within 11 months of enacting the Act, detailing the results of their study on combating modern-day slavery and the recommendations developed. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather necessary information from governmental agencies, and receive evidence to carry out the Act. Additionally, the Commission can request information from departments or agencies when needed. Commission personnel matters are also addressed. Members of the Commission, excluding federal government officers or employees, receive compensation based on the Executive Schedule. Federal government officers or employees serving on the Commission do not receive additional compensation. All members are entitled to travel expenses at authorized rates while away from home. The co-chairpersons of the Commission can appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. They can also determine their compensation independently. The Commission can appoint an executive director and personnel with pay rates not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and temporary services can be procured at specified rates. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal year 2007 with no fiscal year limitation for expenses.
